text: DOC McCOY IS BEING WALKED ACROSS THE COMPOUND BY A UNIFOR GUARD, carrying a riot gun. Other Prisoners around the ya turn and stare as the two men head for the main building.

head_text.subj: DOC WALKS DOWN THE BLEAK HALLWAY

text: in the corridor, they slap hands... the Guard remains at shoulder. Near the end of the passage another Guard clang open a barred door and allows Doc and the First Guard to enter the room where he stands sentry.

A LONG TABLE HAS BEEN SET UP AT THE HEAD OF THE ROOM, sev Prison Officials and Parol Board Members are seated facin the length of the room. Seated at one end of the table is an Irish looking Man; floridly handsome and a bit overweight, his red hair is beginning to grey. The Nameplate in front of him reads J. BEYNON. Doc enters the room and seats himself near two other PRISONERS, the GUARD stands back against the wall.

Another table has been set up; this one near the seated Prisoners, for their LEGAL COUNSELS -- SEVERAL LAWYERS examine papers before them, waiting for the hearing to be A MAN at the center of the large table clears his throat, then begins to speak.
I think we can begin... First parole request Carter "Doc" McCoy... is legal counsel present? A MAN rises from behind the lawyers' table.
Yes. Eugene Stewart representing Mr. McCoy.
watching... taking it all in.
The Man checks the papers before him.

(his voice a bored drone) Carter McCoy, one to five years sentence for armed robbery, first offense in the State of Texas, wanted by the State of Ohio for assault with a deadly weapon and armed robbery...
The State of Ohio has waved jurisdiction, Mr. Chairman. They no longer seek Mr. McCoy in connection with that case.

(adjusting his papers) That is correct. Very well. Mr. McCoy has served four years of his sentence. Prison record satisfactory. Applied for parole on September 5th of this year... The Chairman lowers the paper, looks across to the lawyer
(continuing) Remarks?
We would only again like to call the committee's attention to Mr. McCoy's satisfactory behavior as a prisoner.
Notice is taken. He looks down the table at the dark-suited men.
(continuing) The Board met in closed chambers last week... have you reached a decision regarding Mr. McCoy's request for parole?
His face is taut.
A Second MAN looks across to the Chairman.
(seated near Beynon) Request for parole is denied. The prisoner may re-apply in one calendar year.
lowers his eyes, then looks up at his lawyer. The lawyer avoids Doc's glance., he shuffles the papers in front of him, begins stuffing them into his briefcase.

head_text.subj: AT THE TABLE THE CHAIRMAN FLIPS HIS PAPERS TO A NEW PAGE

text: (still totally without emotion) Very well. The next request for parole is from John Doty. Is legal counsel present?
Yes.
Mr. Doty is serving five to twelve years for embezzlement of corporate funds.

head_text.subj: DOC'S JAW TIGHTENS... HE AGAIN LOOKS AT THE FLOOR
DOC PLAYING CHESS WITH AN OLD CON IN A BLEAK WORK ROOM -

text: torn, magazines, beaten up radio, butt cans filled with s
DOC AND OTHER PRISONERS RUN OUT OF THE GATE LEADING TO th tractor driven carts that will take them to their work ar
DOC AND WORK PARTY HAVE ALREADY ARRIVED AT THE FOREST and begin to cut, file and burn brush. They are always guarde guards, some on horseback.
DOC LEANS AGAINST A WIRE FENCE CHEWING ON AN OVEN match, watches the other prisoners aimlessly wander around the exercise yard.
DOC IS STANDING IN LINE WITH THE OTHER PRISONERS, starchy puddles of food are being ladled out onto the metal trays

head_text.subj: DOC WORKING WITH SEVERAL PRISONERS, ALL OF THEM ON THEIR

text: HANDS AND KNEES, cleaning a long line of open, filthy toilets... a Guard stands nearby.

head_text.subj: DOC SHOWERING IN AN OPEN STALL WITH TWENTY MEN

text: coarse soap and brownish yellow water... Doc has an Ameri Eagle tattooed on one shoulder.
A GUARD LOOKS OUT OVER THE EMPTY EXERCISE YARD... buildin containing bleak cell blocks stand beyond the open compou
A WARDER JANGLES HIS KEY RING AS HE PASSES BY THE IRON do cells.
DOC AND OTHERS WORKING. THE NOISE OF MACHINERY IS deafeni The clatter of the constantly working parts is maddening.
DOC LIES ACROSS A SMALL COT WITHIN HIS SHADOW-CROSSED cel He works carefully at a toothpick suspension bridge. Doc glues the final pieces into place...

Around the cubicle his personal effects can be seen, a picture of an attractive woman, several battered paperbac Doc continues looking at the bridge... then suddenly begi smashing it to pieces with his right fist.
DOC IS SEATED... WAITING. CAROL enters the darkened room seats herself opposite Doc. They are separated by a wide table and net of wire meshing that springs upward from mi point between them.

(big smile, she wants the moment to be an upper) Hello, Doc. He simply stares back at her. Carol's finely honed featur compliment a face that at first glance is pretty,at a sec glance shows willful strength. Doc continues looking at Carol.
I'm sorry. Doc is silent.
It's been raining a lot the last few days. Doc is silent.
We'll try again.
No way. I've got to get out now. Get to Beynon, tell him I'm for sale. His price. She looks at him.
Do it now. She hesitates, tries to touch him through the mesh. Gets and leaves. Doc remains unmoving.

head_text.subj: CAROL MOVES TO THE BACK OF THE LARGE BTJILDING AND UP A R

text: CAROL ENTERS A LEGAL OFFICE, WEARING A SOFT BILLOWY dress She looks very good. A middle aged SECRETARY looks up at Carol. A short baldin man (THE ACCOUNTANT) in his forties works at a large desk across the room from the Secretary. He seems totally occu with his bookwork.

head_text.subj: NEAR THE ACCOUNTANT THREE MEN ARE SEATED ON A DAVENPORT

text: They are dressed casually; by the look of them they might anything at all but all three have commonality; they are professionals. HAYHOE - Thirty years old, buck teeth and blue eyes, a bi ender. CULLY - Well padded strength, large hands and wrists that out of his buttoned shirtsleeves... SWAIN - a little older and a little smarter than the othe two, his narrow features allow no warmth.
SECRETARY Yes?
I want to see Jack Beynon. The Accountant nods to the Secretary, she points Carol towards a door leading to an inner office.
Go right in, Mrs. McCoy.
bed... his hand touching the soft white skin beneath her stomach.

head_text.subj: BACK WITHIN THE OFFICE THE THREE MEN LOOK AFTER CAROL

text: Class - regular?
No. Doc McCoy's old lady.
Cully looks startled.
Jesus. Carol Ainsley?
The very same.
The Doctor took out McGovern for her.
She only rides winning - Class easy class.
Shut up.
pressed against a man's neck. She kisses, then bites a ti portion of skin. BACK TO BEYNON'S OFFICE. HE IS POURING A DRINK.
How are you, Mrs. McCoy?

head_text.subj: CAROL APPROACHES BEYNON'S DESK WITH A NERVOUSLY

text: Ready to talk about my husband, Mr. Beynon.
So the good Doctor comes up again. (then) Please sit down.
He's asked me to come and see you. Beynon looks at her... then lets their eyes meet.
(handing her a drink) Why? Can I help?
Yes, I think you can.

head_text.subj: A MAN'S FINGERS STARING AT THE ANKLET ON THE WOMAN'S LEG

text: drawing an imaginary line upward... a woman's hand wearin wedding ring comes up to meet it.

A UNIFORMED GUARD LEADS DOC DOWN THE HALLWAY, they turn a corner and go into a small private room, Doc is now dress in civilian clothes. Doc catches sight of himself in a small mirror. He stops looking uncertainly at the image... and then moves on wit the guard.

head_text.subj: DOC EXITS THE PRISON AND STANDS WAITING NEAR THE AUTO GAT

text: He looks down the two-lane blacktop road that runs along edge of the penitentiary... Doc turns, looks again at the prison... four years is a long time. A dark Caddy is parked down the road.
THE ACCOUNTANT OR SWAIN SITS BEHIND THE WHEEL. He stares Doc. Doc crosses to him.
Mr. Beynon will see you the day after tomorrow 12:30 at the River Walk. He gestures and drives away.

He leans against a low stone wall that lines the entrance way... The duffel bag rests beside him. A late model Ford approaches, stops near Doc... the passe side door opens from the inside... Carol is driving... Do and Carol look at one another, their eyes holding several moments.

head_text.subj: BOTH CAROL AND DOC ARE VERY TENSE.

text: Hello, Doc.
Hi.
You okay?

(big smile) I'm a lot better off than I was an hour ago. They look at each other for a moment. Carol leans forward Doc, inhibited by the closeness of the prison walls, kiss her lightly, but with affection...
You want to drive?
My license expired, let's get out of here.
Sure... She starts the car, slips it into gear.
THE FORD MOVES ALONG THE DESERTED ROADSIDE, crossing the border and passing into the State of Texas.

head_text.subj: DOC ALTERNATELY STARES AT THE PASSING SCENERY, THEN BACK

text: Carol.
I'm sorry I was late... I got my hair done... the girl was slow.
It looks fine. A pause.
Feel good?
Yeah.
Where do you want to go?
I want to take a walk. He smiles, then reaches over and gently touches a strand Carol's hair.

head_text.subj: THEY PARK THE CAR AND EXIT. DOC MOVES A LITTLE AHEAD OF

text: Carol. He sits on the bank watching the kids play.

head_text.subj: YOUNG BOYS SWING ON A ROPE THAT HANGS OVER THE PALLS

text: COLLEGE KIDS, SOME ARE SWIMMING, SOME STUDYING, SOME just grooving.

head_text.subj: AN OLDER COUPLE SIT ON THE BANK, THEIR FEET IN THE WATER

text: moments. Carol starts to speak but doesn't. He is preoccupied, lost in his own thoughts. Finally he stands, looking down at her. He slowly takes o his coat, folds it, lays it on the grass, then turns and starts walking towards a tree. Suddenly he takes off his shoes, breaks into a run and di for the rope. CAROL IS ALREADY ON HER FEET, HER SWEATER OFF, SHOES kick aside, she runs after him and hits the water with an awkw splash. She is a brief second behind him. THEY COME UP TOGETHER, AND HE LAUGHS WITH THE PURE JOY of being free and alive. She joins him, in his laughter and their arms around each other, they turn as they are swept down stream.

head_text.subj: THROUGH AN OPEN WINDOW A PORTION OF THE EXTERIOR BUILDING

text: BE SEEN... The interior is cozy and Carol. Carol has live here almost two years. On the wall there is a poster (whi will be on the wall of every room that they stay in from on).

Around the room are drying clothes. Carol is ironing with steam iron. Doc is sitting at a table with a Colt .45 in front of him a .32 automatic. He is field stripping. There is a bowl o peaches on the table.
(pointing to the poster) It doesn't look like that.
What do you mean? You've never been there.
I've been there every day for the last four years. She crosses to him and gives him a hug, then returns to h ironing.
What's Beynon got set up?
Small town, small bank, big money. She holds up some 11 by 14 photographs in front of him.
Where did you get those?
I've been doing my homework.
Just like old times?
Better than old times.
I hope so. I am not looking forward to another stretch.
I made a mistake. I'll never make another one.
(after a moment) Where did you get them developed?
Assumed name... Houston.
Good.
How much is the score?
Half a million.
That Beynon's got a long arm.
(after a moment) What do you want for dinner?
Whisky and a peach. She laughs softly, and goes to a cupboard and takes out f bottles of whisky, four glasses and a bowl of ice. Doc sm at her and begins sampling.
(as Doc eats a peach with a sharp knife) How does it taste?
Just the way I remembered. Doc reaches across the table and touches her hand gently.
You been okay?
Pretty good... Made a quick trip to Oregon, saw my brother and the kids. Figured it would be my last chance, unless they wanted to travel.
How's Estelle?
Fatter... some things never change.
Boring.
Nothing's been boring since you found me.
(carefully) That's not all of it.
No. It's been a long time. A pause. He continues stroking her arm.
You go out much?
After four years and now the question comes up.
Couldn't handle it then. Now I can.
(with warmth and a smile) I'm still here, Doc. He stands, kisses her gently. She stands and they move to the stairs.

head_text.subj: THEY ENTER THE BEDROOM AND SIT SIDE BY SIDE ON THE DOUBLE

text: bed. They both sit rigidly. Doc's eyes are on Carol, she stares vacantly expectant. Doc begins to unbutton her blouse, it comes undone with agonizing slowness... Carol pulls her shoulders back help Doc drop the garment down to her waist. Doc hesitates, then carefully touches her shoulder... her hair... he kisses her... Doc gently eases himself away fr Carol.
(he is very tight) Oh Christ... He again moves close... Doc reaches around to unsnap her as Carol places both of her arms around him, holding him tightly...

Doc unsnaps the top fastener, the second one catches, rem unyielding... He closes his eyes for a second... The pres of the moment is again too intense for Doc. Once more he pulls gently away from her. Carol looks at him, her eyes reassuring.
(continuing) I guess I'm kind of...
It's all right.
(explaining the obvious) It's just been a while.
We've got time. We've got a lot of time. I can help you. She stands, begins to remove her skirt.
Wait... give me a minute.
Sure. She sits beside him again, takes his hand in hers...
I'll be okay.
Listen, I'm just as nervous as you are.
Really?
Really. They look at one another. A pause. He kisses her; their embrace pulls them back across the bed.
(continuing) Let me make you feel good, Doctor. But she has little chance as he begins to make love to he

head_text.subj: DOC AND CAROL ARE LYING IN BED.

text: How was it?
Better than I remembered.

head_text.subj: DOC WEARING A ROBE IS COOKING EGGS AND DRINKING WHISKY. C

text: enters.
I was going to fix you breakfast.
You were asleep.
I bought you a lot of new things. She exits and returns with some clothes. He looks at them
Yeah, well, I think I'll stick with what I've got.
Suit yourself. They start eating.
How much does Beynon get? A pause. Carol looks directly at Doc.
$250,000 right off the top.
Is he straight?
You got the parole, didn't you? He picks up a fork and looks through it, as if it is pris bars. She takes his hand and gently takes the fork from h
Thanks again. (then) I 'm glad you waited.
(simply) I couldn't have... much longer.
Yeah... I know.
But I got you out. Didn't I, Doc. I did it. I got you out. Carol begins to laugh softly.
Why are you laughing?

I laugh when I feel happy. Sometimes just thinking of you made me laugh. I had a lot of that. And other times that wasn't enough. I had a lot of that too. I know you find it hard to believe, I'm happy just loving you.
That doesn't hurt.
But sometimes I cried a lot too.
(trying to smile) I didn't. I just waited.

(deeply moved) Want to cry now? Doc smiling, still holding her hand, leads her from the table. THEY CAN'T KEEP THEIR HANDS OFF EACH OTHER AND LAUGHING w complete release they half carry each other into the bedr

head_text.subj: BEYNON IS IN THE BOAT. LUNCH HAS BEEN SET. DOC COMES ABOA

text: You gotta be kidding.
Not at all, just a pleasant way to have lunch. Doc sits. Pedal boats cut through the water in the background.

Glad to see you in civilian clothes. The Accountant and Swain are with Beynon in the boat. Apa from them two pedal boats come up behind Beynon's boat. C and Hayhoe are in one, and two other men are pedalling al in a boat numbered 13.
All it takes is a long arm.
Hard to judge how these things happen. The Parole Board almost never reverses their decisions.
(sarcastic) I guess it was because I was a model prisoner.
This is the only time you and I meet in public. Any business with me, handle it with him... Beynon nods toward the Accountant. He then turns and gest toward the other two men.
(continuing) You're back with your own people now. Got you some professionals.
(flat, hard) I get my own help.

(quiet strength) You run the job, but I run the show. You got two weeks to set it up. It's not a big bank but it handles cash deposits for an o company... half a million... it's a family thing, the bro of the bank director is on the board of directors at Con- Oil... Beacon City. Beynon nods to the two men and they immediately begin to approach in their paddle boat. RUDY BUTLER -- hard eyes and an easy smile; obviously a h gun... PRANK JACKSON -- young, mid-twenties, ruddy face and blon hair; a small man with blank, insensitive features.
(nods to Cully, Swain and Hayhoe) What about them?
They're mine. The one with the moustache is my brother. They stay out of it. We stay clean. As the two men arrive...
(continuing) Rudy Butler, Frank Jackson...
(to Rudy) I heard about you. You work with Miller.
You're out of touch. Cops blew him up.
Where?
Chicago.
You were with him?
Yeah. I got out.
(to Jackson) What about you?
I was backup man on a payroll job. (as Doc looks hard at him) I hit some liquor stores... I drive good.
I drive.
Sure, (to Beynon) You're working on the passports... (as Beynon nods) ... and visas?
They will be ready. You guys do your job.
(irritated) I'll take care of my end.
(big smile) Stay clean.

head_text.subj: THREE TRIPODS HAVE BEEN SET UP NEAR THE HEAVILY CURTAINED

text: window. On two of them huge sets of binoculars have been racked into place, beside them on a tripod is a lectern w notepad and pencil... Doc and Carol peer through the binoculars then write several notations on the paper. Both Doc and Carol drink coffee from paper cups... the residue of dinners served on hotel trays lie about the ro Doc and Carol share a sandwich as they work.
THE BANK CARRIES ON ITS NORMAL MID-DAY ACTIVITY. A Guard enters the building quickly followed by the bank Presiden

head_text.subj: BACK IN THE HOTEL ROOM CAROL AND DOC CONTINUE TO EAT WHIL

text: making further notations.

head_text.subj: CAROL WEARING INCONSPICUOUS WARDROBE STANDS QUIETLY IN LI

text: before a teller's window. As she reaches the window:
I'd like an application for a checking account. She gets it, moves to:

head_text.subj: A TABLE. CAROL MAKES OUT THE APPLICATION AS SHE COOLLY AN

text: unobtrusively eyes the bank.

head_text.subj: DOC, WEARING HIS SUIT AND GLASSES, STANDING AT A TELLER'S

text: window. He moves to the head of the line. He notices a TV camera and a wanted poster showing the fa of wanted bank robbers.
(with a smile) Could I get change for this fifty please? His eyes alert and probing.

head_text.subj: DOC DROPS A LETTER INTO A CORNER MAIL BOX, THEN BUYS A PA

text: from a coin dispenser. His eyes find a Beacon City Police idly talking to a citizen... a police car is near the Officer, the driver's side door open... mounted on the da is a shotgun. Doc tucks the paper under his arm and moves down the street.
DOC WITH BRIEFCASE IS TALKING TO A CIVIL ENGINEER. They b study the detail map of a city sewage system...

head_text.subj: JACKSON PURCHASES A LARGE PAIR OF WIRE CUTTERS.

text: with a pair of scissors.

head_text.subj: RUDY, RANCH DRESSED., IS BUYING A LARGE FLAT BED.
A LARGE ROOM WITHOUT WINDOWS. NEAR THE CENTER SITS A BIG

text: table piled with equipment, watch caps, several different colored raincoats, a huge pair of wirecutters, road maps, chemical containers and four sticks of dynamite, four vis and two passports and several padded U.S. Army, super bul proof vests which are not vests at all, more a shield. Rudy and Jackson stand near the table. Carol is seated. S nervously runs her hand along the edge of one of the road maps. Doc is holding one of the vests. The wall behind the table is dominated by diagrams and ma and photos which show the interior of the Beacon City Ban the Bank vault, and several diagrams of the main street o Beacon City, a Beacon City Police car, and a detailed reproduction of the Beacon City main sewage system, inclu electrical wiring, a detailed road map of the town and various photos of a farmhouse and barn.
... Bank President, three tellers and one guard...
(cutting in) Usually on the right side as you go in.

Nail him first, be careful he doesn't panic and want to shoot somebody. Local police have one car, a rover, shouldn't be in the vicinity at the time we hit unless it's answering an emergency call... if the cop car shows up remember it doesn't have any automatic weapons. Only a shotgun braced on the dashboard. Get into a tight spot, you'll be out of range at forty yards. Then they're down to their side guns.
For exits off Main Street.
Should be light traffic that time of day... the Bank Guard carries a .38. These will stop an M.2 at fifty yards.
He throws the vest on the table.
Just in case someone gets a shot off.
I worked ten years without one, I don't need one now.
Suit yourself.
Okay. How many bank exits?
Two.
What about the vault?
Chambers - Reilly. Time lock opens 20 minutes before they start doing business...
Wire pull over?
One-inch stuff on a three-number combination.
I'm good at that.
I 'm handling the fine stuff. You're back up all the way...
(smile) Whatever you need. To Rudy and Jackson, Doc points to the map and farmhouse picture:
Keep going over these. I don't want anybody getting lost.

(holding two passports and four visas held together by a rubber band) If we are clean Gollie will take us over at Nogales. If we are hot we'll have to try Laughlin at El Paso. She hands Doc the visas, as she puts the two passports in bag.
I'll hang on to these. We don't need them till we get to Gollies. Okay. Any questions?
Aren't we going a little hard?
What do you have in mind?
It's just a walk-in bank. You don't have to be Dillinger for this one.
(a long look at Rudy) Dillinger got killed. Jackson and Rudy begin to exit. The Accountant enters.
(to Accountant) Tell Beynon I want no mistakes. I make four phone calls, his boys better pick up.
I understand.
Beynon has to be alone at the drop ... one car at the ranch and that's it. I won't have the money... she won't know where it is until I'm sure it's clear.
He understands.
Make sure everybody does.
DOC AND CAROL ARE GETTING READY FOR BED. It is the night before the robbery. Carol stands looking in the mirror.
You know how I feel?
My mind's not on guessing games. Carol turns away from the mirror.
Promise you won't laugh.
(shakes his head; smiles) If it's funny I'm going to laugh.
I feel like the night before the first day of school.
That bad? Carol laughs.
You promised not to laugh. They both laugh. Long beat. Carol gets into bed. Doc is already in bed.
It will be such a relief not to have to think about it any more.
Waiting's hard. You never learn how.
You know I've actually gotten tired waiting sometimes... worn out waiting.
At least you were outside.
It doesn!t make much difference where you are, if you're waiting, Doc.
Bullshit.
I mean it.
I know you do. But it is different. (before she can interrupt suddenly up a notch) It's different. (quieting down) We'll be all right tomorrow.
We are always going to be all right tomorrow. I'd like to be all right a few todays.
We're going to have a lot of those, (easy, embracing her tightly) We're just going to get the money and then go all the way.
(smiling at him) ... and live happily ever after.

STICKS of dynamite, two tubes of Naptha, a lot of prima c and one small, dark percussion cap. CAROL SITS BEHIND THE WHEEL OF THE GREY PANEL TRUCK as it prowls smoothly down a brush-lined Central Texas road. Ca drives calmly, professionally...

head_text.subj: DOC IS BEHIND CAROL, AT THE BACK OF THE

text: VAN. He wears a jacket and watch cap. Doc is squatted down, quickly activating another timing mechanism, checking the clock-face on the bomb against his wristwatch... with a quick, dexterous movement, he places a bomb into the two large grocery bags at his feet. After burying the explosives within each sack, he covers the bombs with crumpled wastepaper.
The grocery bags are then gently shoved forward, resting against the wheel well of the truck. As Doc looks at Carol...

PARKED ALONG A SECLUDED PATHWAY, facing the highway which lies a quarter of a mile away. He has on a trench coat buttoned to the neck and his sail watch cap... he stares at the highway. THE PANEL TRUCK SLIDES BY...

head_text.subj: A FULLY-LOADED HAY TRUCK RUMBLES DOWN THE ROAD .
JACKSON IS DRIVING, HE WEARS A DARK RAINCOAT AND WATCH CA

text: RUDY CHECKS HIS PISTOL. He shoves the pistol into the sid pocket of his raincoat. Rudy starts the engine... then sl the car into gear...
A sleepy, traditional municipality...

head_text.subj: A DAPPER GENTLEMAN IN HIS EARLY FIFTIES WALKS ALONG THE

text: SIDEWALK. He is the PRESIDENT of the First Bank of Beacon City -- nodding to a few passersby, he stops at the front door of the bank, knocks twice. A BANK GUARD opens the do and the Bank President moves inside.
sign that reads:
Founded 1911 Hours: 9:00 AM to 2:00 PM Weekdays Only
THE PRESIDENT SNAPS ON A BANK OF IRRIDESCENT LIGHTS. Seve TELLERS have begun setting up for the day's commerce...

head_text.subj: DOC SHIFTS HIS POSITION SLIGHTLY, THEN PULLS HIS .45 OU

text: beneath his jacket. Doc breaks out the   clip, examines i snaps it back to position. He replaces   the gun under hi jacket -- the gesture seemingly more a   mannerism than a precaution. A huge pair of tongs and the massive wire cutters rest on floor of the truck near Doc, along with a black leather suitcase. CAROL IN THE DRIVER'S SEAT, Beacon City appears on the horizon through the windshield...

THE PRESIDENT BEGINS TURNING THE COMBINATION on the massi door as the vault begins to open... RUDY - IN THE BUICK - DRIVING DOWN THE ROADWAY near the outskirts of town. A Texas Highway Patrol car passes, mov in the opposite direction...

then checks his watch. A WATCH FACE SHOWS THE TIME AT 8:56. THE WATCH BELONGS TO DOC. He looks expectantly towards Ca THE PANEL TRUCK is now within the commercial district of Beacon City. Rudy's Buick is visible a hundred yards behi THE HAY TRUCK drives off Main Street and into an open fie near a corner of the town. Jackson jumps down out of the cab of the truck and crosse the sidewalk. Rudy's Buick pulls over and Jackson gets into the passeng seat. The Buick then cruises back out onto Main Street... CAROL - IN THE VAN - APPROACHES AN INTERSECTION. Through truck's window a traffic signal appears. RUDY PULLS THE BUICK OFF THE MAIN DRAG and onto a side street. Another turn and he again moves parallel to the M Street...

THE BANK PRESIDENT LEAVES THE VAULT, allowing the heavy d to stand open. A LATTICE-WORK BARRIER made of wrought-iron is pulled acr the vault opening... the Bank President snaps the latch-l closed. CAROL - IN THE PANEL TRUCK. She pulls the van carefully t stop at the intersection as the stoplight blinks red... S turns her eyes back to Doc... DOC, CATCHES HER LOOK, then instantly springs into action reaches down, pulls a hatch-like cover up from the floor the truck, revealing the road below... a portion of a man cover is visible.
(barking the words) Two feet forward...

head_text.subj: CAROL ROLLS THE TRUCK SLIGHTLY FORWARD

text: ON THE STREET - SEVERAL CARS can be seen moving up behind panel truck. DOC GRABS THE TONGS, inserts the ends into the manhole co notches. He lifts the tongs and slides the manhole cover forward. Doc drops down through the truck hatchway and in open manhole, carrying the huge cutters with him. As he disappears from sight... 98 RUDY DRIVING ON THE SIDE AVENUE, still moving parallel to Main Street. The Buick is now geographically well forw of the panel truck. Jackson stares at his watch.

Now! Rudy makes a sharp left. The car accelerates, its wheels begin to quietly whine. Main Street comes back into view... CAROL WATCHING THE SIGNAL... still red... A MAN IN A PONTIAC eases to a stop behind the panel truck watches the signal. DOC STANDING IN THE SEWER PIPE. He turns on a flashlight, moves ahead. His feet slosh through the six-inch-high mur water.
Doc shines the light on several ankle-thick conduit lines that run along the sewer wall... He moves down the dark o corridor...
THE GUARD OPENS THE FRONT DOOR, allowing the morning PATR to enter.
THE PRESIDENT SMILES UPON SEEING THE CUSTOMERS. He looks to the wood-frame clock on the far wall.

RUDY - IN THE BUICK - MAKES ANOTHER LEFT TURN, now back o Main Street. THE BANK APPEARS A HALF-BLOCK AWAY through the car window Rudy and Jackson pull their watch caps down over their fa the holes cut into the caps are wide enough to recognize disparity between their features... MAIN STREET - THE TRAFFIC SIGNAL has now blinked to green CAROL IS GRINDING AWAY AT THE DEAD ENGINE of the panel truck... THE MAN IN THE PONTIAC leans on his HORN... other cars be him begin to HONK. CAROL LEANS OUT OF THE CAB OF THE PANEL TRUCK and gesture for the cars to pass her. She again GRINDS away at the engine. DOC'S WATCH - SHOWING 9:01. DOC STANDS AT A MASSIVE CONNECTING BOX where four 112 str of the conduit intersect. He puts the wire cutters to the first conduit, grasps the insulated handles and with a crunching POP, he cuts through the conduit with one bite. immediately starts on the next strand. CAROL - ON MAIN STREET - trying to start the engine. THE BUICK SLAMS TO A STOP IN FRONT OF THE BANK. Rudy Il4 Jackson pull open the car doors. DOC CUTTING THE LAST AND LARGEST CONDUIT.

THE BANK GUARD is placing a local high school basketball schedule and display into position. SEVERAL PATRONS have formed small lines and are transacti business with the Tellers. The wall clock shows the time at 9:02. RUDY AND JACKSON BURST THROUGH THE GLASS DOOR. They stand shoulder to shoulder, guns extended the full length of th arms. Beneath the mask Rudy's smile is visible. THE BANK GUARD LOOKS UP PROM THE BASKETBALL DISPLAY. His widen... both guns are leveled directly at him... simultaneously the lights go out... THE BANK PRESIDENT DESPERATELY PUSHES THE ALARM BUTTON ne his desk. (INSERT: Button and bell.) Nothing happens. CAROL - ON MAIN STREET - trying to start the engine.

THE D.D.S. TORTURES A BALDING PATIENT with a drill. The PATIENT groans, lifts one leg in the air from the pain. When the power goes, the Dentist quizzically raises the d and examines it. The Patient pants in relief.

Superior technology, my ass. AN ELECTRIC WEATHER/TIME INDICATOR - above the town squar as the bulbs dim... DOC RUNNING DOWN THE SEWER; stopping at the manhole he scrambles up the permanent ladderway, tossing his wire cutters up into the truck parked over him. CAROL - IN THE DRIVER'S SEAT - again she tries to start t engine. DOC PULLING HIMSELF BACK UP INTO THE VAN with a gymnastic thrust he quickly slides the manhole cover with the tongs CAROL - the engine still won't start. DOC DROPS THE HATCH DOOR back down into place on the floo the truck...

(snapping his look to Carol) Okay. CAROL TURNS THE IGNITION SWITCH BACK ON... CAROL - AS THE ENGINE ROARS TO LIFE she engages the gearshift. The truck begins to move forward. Suddenly, th motor does STALL. DOC'S PACE TIGHTENS. The cars behind the van continue HONKING. CAROL - AGAIN GRINDING AWAY AT THE ENGINE. Her lips are compressed into a thin line... After a moment... the moto catches, the truck again moves forward. DOC PICKS UP THE LARGE BLACK SUITCASE from the floor of t panel truck, then begins to move toward the cab and Carol THE PANEL TRUCK WHIPS OFF MAIN STREET and onto a side ave Carol pulls the van up to the curbway, jerking to a stop. DOC IS NOW IN THE FRONT SEAT BESIDE CAROL. He pulls the t door open, then hesitates. He touches her arm, their eyes meet briefly, both their faces warming for a moment. Doc gives her a casual wink then quietly exits the truck.
DOC TURNS AND BEGINS WALKING toward an open alleyway. Beh him the panel truck pulls smoothly away.

He turns again, now moving down a totallydeserted side al The alley opens at one end onto a back street; the opposi end is bounded by a large brick building. Doc removes his pistol from his coat pocket, then approaches a doorway al the side of the brick building. At the last moment he pul down the watch cap mask.
RUDY DISENGAGES THE LATCH on the side door.
DOC KICKS THE DOOR OPEN with a violent jerk of his leg.

RUDY'S GUN IS TRAINED PROM THE BACK OF THE BUILDING over Tellers and Patrons, spread-eagled across the floor. Thei heads are down; several of them are trembling. DOC STANDS HOLDING THE .45 IN ONE HAND, suitcase in the other. He moves into the building, shutting the door behi him. RUDY IS NOW STATIONED NEAR THE FRONT DOOR, ready to inter any incoming bank patrons -- he covers the room from the opposite Jackson. Rudy stands near the Bank Guard's outstretched right hand The Guard's head is bloodied from Rudy's pistol whipping. gun has been kicked against the wall. A short distance aw Rudy is watching. THE BANK PRESIDENT lies face down on the floor, directly under the arc of Jackson's gun... who is continually turn to watch the Guard. DOC QUICKLY CROSSES THE DISTANCE between the side door an the vault, passing the Bank President. He slips the .45 i his jacket side pocket, sets down the suitcase, then eith cuts the lock or picks it.

(looking at his watch) 19 seconds. CAROL - IN THE VAN - She has stopped the panel truck near deserted lot where the hay truck is parked. She drops the bomb-laden grocery bag inside the truckbed. moves back towards the van...

DOC FINISHES,, RIPS THE DOOR OPEN, lifts the suitcase and moves into the vault. RUDY LOOKS AT THE BLOODIED GUARD, notes the distance separating the man from his gun. Though unconscious, the Guard's head begins to move. JACKSON HOLDS HIS GUN HAND FULLY EXTENDED. Again he takes brief moment to glance nervously over to the open vault a at the Guard. ANGLES AND INSERTS - THE VAULT is lined with safety depos boxes and large cabinet drawers.

A metal table stands off-center, the black suitcase resti on its surface. Doc opens the satchel. He then pulls open of the cabinet drawers nearby and begins tossing banded m pads into the open suitcase. THE BANK PRESIDENT LIES NEAR THE OPEN VAULT. He listens t the SOUNDS of Doc at work. He slightly cranes his neck, trying to get a look at the thief inside the vault. RUDY WATCHING THE FRONT DOOR. A PATRON enters; Rudy gestu with the gun... she hits the deck. JACKSON IS GETTING MORE NERVOUS by the minute... DOC continues working within the vault. THE WOMAN, now on the floor, quietly crying. JACKSON watching the Guard. RUDY watching Jackson. Calling out time. THE BANK GUARD, glassy-eyed, but conscious; he has the lo of a prizefighter who has just suffered a knockout, but i ready for one more round. THE BANK PRESIDENT in his prone position. He looks at Jackson, then to the vault. THE PANEL TRUCK - now at the other end of Main Street. CAROL EXITS THE VAN, carries the second sack to a large rubbish bin in front of an empty store. She deposits the grocery bag... DOC WORKING. The suitcase is now filled. He snaps the fasteners shut . DOC EXITS THE VAULT after withdrawing his .45 from his co pocket . JACKSON SEES DOC LEAVE THE VAULT. He edges around the sid the tellers' cages toward the front of the bank.

head_text.subj: DOC MOVES TOWARDS JACKSON'S OLD VANTAGE POINT NEAR THE SI

text: DOOR. He passes the bank president.
DOC CARRIES THE HEAVY SUITCASE IN HIS LEFT HAND. He gestu to Rudy and Jackson with his pistol while moving towards side door.

head_text.subj: JACKSON HALF RUNS PASSING RUDY ON HIS WAY TO THE FRONT

text: ENTRANCE still watching the Bank Guard.

head_text.subj: THE BANK GUARD STILL PUNCH DRUNK PULLS HIMSELF UP TO HIS

text: HANDS and knees... the Guard looks at his pistol.

head_text.subj: DOC STOPS AT THE KICKED IN SIDE DOOR. HE COVERS THE ENTIR

text: bank with his gun.

head_text.subj: THE BANK GUARD BEGINS TO CRAWL WITH AGONIZING SLOWNESS

text: towards his pistol.

head_text.subj: JACKSON NOW AT THE FRONT DOOR IS PARALYZED WATCHING THE
CAROL PARKS THE VAN, CROSSES TO A FORD, GETS IN, DRIVES A
DOC AND RUDY. BOTH SEE WHAT IS ABOUT TO HAPPEN.

text: (shouts) Just pick it up.

Don't! JACKSON PULLS THE TRIGGER THREE TIMES. THE BANK GUARD'S BODY turns end-over-end from Jackson's bullets. Some of the bank Patrons SCREAM, others SOB with fright. DOC - His eyes are furious. RUDY AND JACKSON - Rudy shoves Jackson out the front door DOC COVERS THEIR EXIT, then slips out the side door and i the alley.
RUDY GUNS THE BUICK FORWARD, the wheels tearing at the asphalt. Jackson's shoulders rock back as the big car accelerates.

DOC, GUN AND SUITCASE IN HAND, nears the end of the alleyway. CAROL - IN A FORD - suddenly pulls up, filling the roadwa opening. DOC TOSSES THE SUITCASE into the back of the car... then slides the pistol under his coat and slips behind the whe as Carol slides over to the passenger seat.
DOC PULLS OFF THE WATCH CAP MASK; his face taut. THE FORD SMOKES OFF as Doc kicks it into gear...

THE BUICK STREAKS DOWN THE CENTER OF THE ROADWAY... Two b detonate into fireballs... The Hay truck blazes upward, b instantly igniting. The grange at the opposite end of town becomes an orange- flame inferno... Traffic stalls on the boulevard; Drivers and Pedestrians at the twin blazes. RUDY ZIG ZAGS THE BUICK ALONG. Maneuvering through the stopped traffic. DOC SLIDES THE FORD THROUGH A RIGHT AND LEFT TURN, emergi onto smoke-covered Main Street. The speeding Ford avoids a halting car, then suddenly spi out of control, jumps across the sidewalk, splinters a wo bench, and finally slides in a complete circle across the grass of a small park.

head_text.subj: DOC LOOKS MORE THAN A LITTLE EMBARRASSED AS CAROL STARES

text: AT him. POLICE CARS ROAR BY THEM.

head_text.subj: DOC ZIPS THE CAR OFF THE GRASS AND BACK ONTO THE TRAFFIC

text: RUDY DRIVING THROUGH THE BEDLAM. Suddenly a gun appears i his right hand, aimed at Jackson. The pistol roars bucks, roars, bucks again. Jackson is shot through the head twic

head_text.subj: THE FORD IS SEVERAL BLOCKS BEHIND RUDY. DOC DOWNSHIFTS

text: avoiding stalled cars. Carol grasps at both the seat and dashboard handholds to maintain her balance. THE BUICK EMERGES THROUGH DENSE PLUMES OF SMOKE. Fire lic along the one edge of the sidewalk. RUDY IN THE BUICK HAS NOW ALMOST CLEARED THE TOWN. He tea along the highway... sweating a little but becoming cool. is a pro. His watch cap is now removed. ON THE CURVE - Jackson's body is kicked out of the automo and bounces across the pavement. DOC IN THE FORD POWERS ALONG. He approaches the flaming building, then hits the brakes as ... A BIG DIESEL TRUCK AND TRAILER is coming in the opposite direct ion,, jack-knifes across the road, desperately try to avoid the cars stopped in the middle of the street . DOC, AS THE TRUCK AND TRAILER SUDDENLY APPEAR THROUGH the smoke in front of him, throws the car broadside into a fo wheel drift. Now sideways, then straight, he bumps across sidewalk, over a patio of a house, knocking down two pill through a parking lot, taking with it a large cleaners si then bores back onto the road. RUDY IN THE BUICK STROKING ALONG THE OPEN HIGHWAY. Looks the rear view mirror. RUDY'S POV - THROUGH THE BUICK'S REAR WINDOW, BLACK smoke visible billowing skyward. DOC AND CAROL IN THE FORD NOW DRIVING CALMLY THROUGH the countryside. A police car with light turning and siren wailing passes them, heading for the conflagration in Bea City. Doc's eyes follow the Patrol Car until it disappear from sight. THE BUICK - SERIES OF ANGLES - IT pulls off the highway a bumps down a dirt road. Rudy strains to hold the big car the rutted pathway.

The dirt road becomes a lane. A farm house and barn appear at a clearing. Rudy powers t car up a fairly steep hill, the crest of which is occupie a seemingly abandoned and dilapidated house barn. RUDY JUMPS OUT OF THE BUICK, trots to the front of the ba and pulls the double-doors open. A station wagon with woo panel or the usual painted panel sides can be seen within THE FORD SWEEPS OFF THE HIGHWAY and onto the dirt road. WITHIN THE FORD - DOC IS DRIVING. Carol peels off her sweater. She has worn a faded blouse underneath... She pu a ribbon; her hair falls changing her appearance. RUDY - IN THE BARN - The Buick is now parked near the Sta Wagon. Standing in the shadows, he intently reloads his g then moves towards the large doors of the barn. CAROL - IN THE PASSENGER SEAT OF THE FORD - she watches a Doc drives up the lane... RUDY stands outside the barn as the car approaches. DOC STUDIES RUDY THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD, watching him wip his face with a soiled rag as the car pulls closer...

DOC PULLS THE FORD TO A STOP just within the double doors passes Rudy, leaving a clear exit pathway for the getaway station wagon. DOC JUMPS OUT OF THE FORD AS SOON AS the ignition switch cut; Carol a beat behind him on the opposite side. Rudy moves into the archway created by the barn's open do He stands almost in silhouette as the bright sunlight bre around him. Doc snaps open the door of the car, his back turned to Ru He reaches into the back seat and grasps the black suitca not by the middle handle but by each end, as if it contai a great weight.
(speaking over his shoulder, not looking at Rudy) Where's Jackson? Rudy withdraws the pistol from under his raincoat.

(pointing his gun lazily at Doc, supremely confident) He didn't make it, Doc... you didn't either. Doc straightens, still holding the suitcase. He starts to turn to Rudy, eyes wide, helpless. Carol fumbles for the in her purse. Rudy extends his arm, ready to begin the execution. Doc swings the suitcase around slowly, seemingly ready to fac Rudy's bullets... then he shoots Rudy in the middle of th chest, Doc's .45 slug driving him backward. Doc has concealed the pistol in his hand with the satchel drops the suitcase with his first shot, FIRES again, blas Rudy in the middle. Two large holes now show at the chest Rudy's raincoat. Rudy is knocked back over the hillock, tumbling down the precipice and into a grassy meadow below. Doc stands at t crest of the hill. He looks down as Rudy's body stops turning. Doc shifts the .45 to his right hand. Rudy's body lies still. DOC TURNS QUICKLY AWAY PROM THE HILLTOP, not giving Rudy' body a second glance. Carol, gun in hand, stands outside barn, transfixed.
How did you know? Doc doesn't answer, motioning her into the car... the get car... as she starts to change clothes... he reloads. Doc takes a long look at Carol. THEY GET IN THE CAR AND LEAVE.
CAROL IS DRIVING., tooling comfortably along a country ro Doc is beside her, the suitcase resting in the back seat. After several moments of silence:
What about the bank?
(after a moment) Jackson panicked and nailed the guard.
Carol takes a deep breath,, then turns her look at the si window.
Oh, Christ. Doc leans forward., snaps on the radio.

RUDY BUTLER STUMBLES BACK OVER THE CREST OP THE HILLOCK a onto the pathway in front of the barn. His figure is slig grotesque; the raincoat shows two holes from Doc's .45 sl along with considerable dirt and grass stains picked up o his ass-over-tea kettle trip to the bottom of the hill. H obviously in some pain, his walk is a half-lurch.

RUDY TURNS ON A RUSTED TAP which sends all-pocketed water gurgling down into a mold-covered trough. Rudy pulls off yellow raincoat, revealing the fact he has worn one of th padded bullet-proof vests. Rudy undoes the vest, lets it to his feet. A huge crimson stain shows at his collarbone RUDY TOUCHES THE BLOOD WITH HIS RIGHT HAND, then looks at hand. Breathing heavily he kneels down and begins to spla the purling water across his face and then he laughs.

head_text.subj: DIALOGUE COMES ON THE RADIO DESCRIBING THE ROBBERY.

text: stolen.

We got between four and five. Carol starts to open the bag and count. Doc flicks off the radio then cracks open the windwing. D reflectively studies the roadside ahead. They are heading along a comfortable tree and meadowlined thoroughfare tha carries only a sparse amount of traffic. Doc's eyes suddenly narrow on the road ahead.
(now noticing the road) Doc...
(flat) I see it...

ON THE ROAD AHEAD HIGHWAY PATROLMEN HAVE FORMED a traffic barricade. Several cars and trucks are being waved throug the check-point. Wearing sunglasses and Stetson hats, the Uniformed officers make a cursory glance into each passin vehicle. DOC ANALYZES THE SITUATION WITHOUT CHANGING EXPRESSION He slips the station wagon up behind a pickup truck in the l of slowly-passing vehicles. She turns, starts to reach into the back. Doc gently catc her arm, preventing her from moving further.

They're looking for three men... remember? A YOUNG OFFICER looks into the cab of the pickup, then glances at the empty flatbed. Another PATROLMAN flanks th other side of the truck, repeating the procedure. Several Patrol Cars, fully loaded with additional OFFICERS, are parked nearby. The pickup truck is waved through. The sta wagon rolls up to the check-point. DOC ROLLS DOWN HIS WINDOW. He smiles and nods to the Youn Patrolman.

(big smile) What's the problem? CAROL STUDIES THE OFFICER on her side of the car through closed window... the Officer peers back at her then into rear seat. THE STATION WAGON is waved ahead without a second glance the Patrolman; Doc accelerates away from the roadblock... After a moment, Doc leans forward, snapping on the radio.

Inside the barn, behind the wheel of the panel truck, Rud matted black hair is in contrast to his blanched face. He starts the engine, painfully bringing it to a ROAR. The p truck leaps crazily forward, careening across the barn fl SMASHING through the edge of the wooden doors as it burst out into the sunlight.
The station wagon rolls down the main street and stops ne an outdoor phone booth at a filling station.

head_text.subj: DOC SHUTS OFF THE ENGINE, PULLS OPEN HIS DOOR.
DOC MOVES INSIDE THE PHONE BOOTH CARRYING A FIST-FULL

text: of loose change. He begins to dial...

head_text.subj: THE PHONE RINGS. THE ACCOUNTANT LIFTS THE RECEIVER.

text: I 'm here. He presses a button on the intercom.
Yeah. He presses a button on the intercom. ANOTHER PHONE IN THE OFFICE. HAYHOE PICKS UP THE PHONE.
Yeah. He presses a button on the intercom.

head_text.subj: SWAIN TURNS AND REACHES FOR THE RECEIVER.
DOC MOVES TOWARDS THE WAGON, CLIMBS INSIDE.
DOC SLAMS THE DOOR SHUT. CAROL LOOKS ACROSS AT HIM.

text: They checked in.
Call the ranch, tell Beynotr we'll leave his cut here --
Why?
There are three men dead.
So what. I've got to give him his money. That was our end of the deal.
He might be ready to chop us up.
Do it my way. He starts the engine. The station wagon pulls away.

head_text.subj: AS IT PULLS OUT OF THE SMALL TOWN.

text: Tell me about Beynon's ranch.
I've never "been there... When we met it was in his office. Doc looks at her for a moment.
(continuing; hesitant) Do you trust him?
I just figure the percentages. He wouldn't try a cross until he's got the money.
Let's send his cut back -- Just keep going.
If we make a mistake., he'll burn us. You make a deal, you're always better keeping your end up.
I don't want to go there.
Do it my way. The wagon continues moving down the road.

TWO HOURS BEFORE SUNSET. A CHILL SOUTHWEST WIND is blowin The station wagon appears, moving slowly down the roadway bouncing along its rutted surface. AT A SMALL INTERSECTION TWO MAIL BOXES STAND CLOSE to one another. The name Beynon is printed in black paint on one the letter bins. Doc stops the wagon momentarily, looks a the box, then turns down the indicated road.
THE STATION WAGON clears the crest of a sage brush hill a passes camera.

DOC PARKS THE WAGON UNDER A GNARLED COTTONWOOD TREE in fr of the house. As he shuts off the engine, he pulls the .4 out of his coat pocket and shoves it into his waistband. Carol watches the gesture. Doc starts to open the car doo then hesitates.

You can wait here... I'll wrap it up fast. DOC STEPS OUT OF THE WAGON, then pulls the leather suitca out of the back. He quietly shuts the car door and moves around the side of the house, toward the barn/garage at t rear. HE LOOKS CAREFULLY around the area, his eyes searching fo signs of Beynon's men. Nothing seemingly amiss, he moves toward the front door, tries it, moves away. Doc crosses to the back screen door of the house. After another moment, Doc quietly opens the screen door and ent the house.
DOC MOVES THROUGH THE SERVICE PORCH/PANTRY and into the kitchen.

BEYNON SITS AT THE LONG KITCHEN TABLE] head on hand, eyes slightly glared... on the checkered oilcloth in front of is a quart bottle of Jim Beam, now half full. He's drinki the sour mash straight with a water chaser. DOC LOOKS STEADILY AT BEYNON for a moment,, sets the suit down on the floor, then crosses to the sink, picks up a g and sits down at the table. Doc pours himself a drink, ta a sip.
Hello, McCoy.
Beynon.
(swishing the drink) News said two persons killed. Except for a faint thickness of speech, Beynon seems quit sober. Beynon wears a .38 Detective Special C.T.G. in a w leather belly holster.
Three... Rudy got ambitious.
And you got him...
That's right. Doc looks at Beynon, notes his gun, then continues stacki the money.
What about your wife?
What about her? (moving right to the business at hand) Let's c ut up the money, I want to get North.

head_text.subj: PARKED UNDER THE COTTONWOOD AT THE FRONT OF THE HOUSE. CA
SITS CHEWING GUM... LINES OF STRAIN HAVE FORMED ACROSS HE

text: Your wife told me no one would be killed.
You hired Jackson and Rudy., not me.
They may nail me into this now, McCoy.
That's your problem.
(smiles) You know, you and I may be two of a kind.
No way. I always do my own work. Beynon smiles and slops three fingers of whiskey into Doc glass.
Here. I understand the way you feel. As a matter of fact, you and I might share a great many feelings... Beynon drinks from his glass. Doc continues counting the money.
(snaps the words) I'm in a hurry.
You still don't get the picture do you? I've always heard what a smart ass operator you are.

No applause! Beynon pauses a moment. Doc looks steadily across the tab into BeynonTs eyes. Prom beyond there might be the quiet sound of a screen door opening. Beynon gets out of the ch stands beside the table.

Let's examine the situation. One, an extremely attractive woman. Then, there's the woman's husband, a skillful bank robber serving a long sentence in prison. Three, a man with political influence, a man who can easily get a parole for a convict... why should he? Beynon sips his glass slowly. Doc's hand edges down towar his waist band.
(continuing) A simple reason, McCoy. The obvious reason. To rob a bank.
I knew that life didn't add up to the obvious when I was 8.
(cautiously) What do you add up to here?
One. The radio's rappin' about $750^000. We only got a half a million.
A little more was taken out before. (a beat) My brother's a director of that Bank, Mr. McCoy... I had a few pressing debts.
So we did that crackerbox... to cover for you.
(smiles., nodding) The obvious. (as his smile fades) But we are both not interested in that right now.
No. (a long beat) My old lady must have made a lot of promises.
Close... but it takes a hell of a lot more than promises to pull the kind of strings I pulled.

I bet. Doc senses a movement from the shadows behind Beynon. Tur his head slightly, Doc can see Carol standing at the entr to the kitchen. She holds a .32 automatic... the pistol s to be pointed directly at Doc.
You wouldn't have come here when you were eight3 Mr. McCoy. As the gun continues to be pointed directly at Doc.
(continuing) Don't think too badly of her... After all, you were in jail a long time and she is a healthy young woman.

(riding over Beynon's words) Get it over with... CAROL FIRES the automatic. The big gun belches the full s in a stuttering EXPLOSION... the slide remains back and i ejected position. BEYNON is driven back to the kitchen wall. He SHRIEKS alo the noise strangely like laughter... his body flattens against the surface, slips downward^ riddled by the big b slugs... Doc stands momentarily frozen against the overtu table. He looks up from Beynon's crumpled body. Carol tak two steps forward, then drops the automatic, sending it clattering and spinning away across the floor. DOC looks at Carol, their eyes find each other. He turns, moves to the sink, splashes water across his face, then f a glass of water from the tap ... drinks it; he looks bac her. CAROL stands watching Doc, tears scream down her cheeks. DOC crosses to Carol, takes her arm, picks up the gun, sp shells and the suitcase, then leads her out of the kitche toward the back door. Beynon's body has slipped from sigh only a few traces of blood show along the white wall.

Rudy is driving along an open highway. Rudy mouths inane lyrics to the radio, one arm on the wheel, the other clutching his wound. A small sign near a mailbox catches Rudy's eye. He swings the panel truck around in a U-turn, then pulls into the long dirt driveway of an isolated far house.
Practice of Veterinary Medicine.

THE STATION WAGON IS PARKED ALONG THE CEMENT ROAD, standi in isolation against the vast Texas b.g. Doc stands away from the car, his back turned to it ... gazing at the horizon. Carol is in the wagon but the passenger side door is open her legs dangle outside the car as she looks steadily at ground. Doc suddenly turns, walks to her and gives her a stinging slap across the face.
Stupid. Tears begin to roll down Carol's face.
(continuing) Why didn't you tell me?
There wasn't any way to explain it.
Yeah.
You sent me to him.
When I got out, why didn't you tell me where it was?
What the hell do you want? Mary Tyler Moore?
Who's she?
She's on TV.
If you don't start telling the truth... (breaks off)
What do we do?
(quietly) We keep going.

Swain sleeps on the davenport. Cully and Hayhoe sit at tw sides of Beynon's large desk, playing a game of checkers. Hayhoe seems to have Cully badly beaten ... The Accountan enters the room. The block on the wall shows eight o'cloc straight up.
Let's go. The two men abandon their game. Cully kicks the sofa, awakening Swain. He groggily gets to his feet.
The station wagon enters the building. Doc takes a bright orange ticket from an ATTENDANT behind a glass window, th accelerates the wagon up a rampway leading to the upper levels of the building.
checks his watch momentarily as he prowls the wagon between long rows of automobiles.
WHINE through a sweeping turn within the auto park's uppermost level -- through the building's portals the bri morning sun can be seen reflecting off the city's rooftop

DOC PULLS THE WAGON to an abrupt halt within a parking st - at an isolated area. He steps out onto the concrete flooring, slams the door shut. Doc turns away from the car. As he approaches the elevato Doc tears the orange auto park stub into fragments and dr them into a trash bin without missing a stride.

CAROL IS STANDING IN A TICKET LINE THAT MOVES slowly fowa She struggles, clutching the heavy, money laden suitcase her oversize purse between both arms. The line of ticket buyers moves forward .just fast enough to make it impract to set the suitcase down. The station is ancient, vaultli Baggage lockers line the perimeter of the lobby and exten off into clumped rows within the wings of the station. CAROL APPROACHES THE TICKET WINDOW. She places the suitca flush against the base of the counter and holds it tightl place with one leg. Carol pops open her purse... a clumsy item in itself... as she lifts her wallet and the elderly ticket-seller looks across to her.
Two day coach tickets -- on the Flyer.

Thirty-four fifty-six with tax leaves in forty-five minutes, gate three. Carol pays the tariff, places the tickets into her purse along with the change. Wearily, she labors the satchel ba into her hand, then turns and begins to slowly walk down seemingly acres-wide station promenade. NEAR A PORTICO WITHIN THE MAIN LOBBY, Carol sits uncomfortably on a shiny wooden bench -- the suitcase res on the floor pressed tightly between her ankles. She glan across the promenade walls, her eyes finding:

CAROL STARES ACROSS THE ROOM at the scattering of passeng waiting on the wooden seats opposite from her. Carol's nervous boredom increases; she looks down at her pretends to find something wrong with her nails and begin rubbing the cuticles. Carol finally rises impulsively fro the bench, immediately reaching for the brown leather satchel.

CAROL WALKS BACK DOWN THE PROMENADE while carrying   the suitcase. As other baggage-laden passengers scurry   arou her, she looks across the arcade, her eyes finding   a gl walled Cocktail Lounge. She hesitates, then begins   to t in that direction. A BANK OF LOCKERS STANDS NEAR THE COCKTAIL LOUNGE. As Car approaches, an elderly WOMAN deposits a coin in one of th numbered lockers, opens the metal door and places a small suitcase inside. Closing and re-locking the door, the Wom quickly moves away. Having noted the woman and more than tired of hauling her burden around the station, Carol ste to the end locker, takes a quarter out of her purse, then studies the time scarred operating instructions on the fa of the locker. She slips the quarter into the slot and op the locker door. As Carol bends to pick up the suitcase, locker door swings closed... She tries to open it but the door has re-locked itself... Carol quite disgusted with h predicament, again sets the suitcase down and pulls a qua out of her change purse. As she again reads the numbered directions, a YOUNG MAN appears at her shoulder. THE MAN IS A PROTOTYPE OF URBAN SLEAZINESS, Doberman Pins features are broken by a weedybrown moustache, a cheap corduroy suit is set off by an oddly matched bow tie. The Man's appearance suggests a kind of drug store dapperness

Kind of tricky, isn't it? She turns, startled by his sudden proximity. In one smoot movement the Dapper Man plucks the quarter from Carol's h deposits it in the slot and swings the locker door open. Setting the heavy suitcase inside, he closes the door, te it to show that it has been re-locked, then removes the key from the lock an puts it into Carol's hand. She is intimidated momentarily the Man's sudden appearance and forcefulness, as well as intentions.
Thank you.

(toothy grin) No trouble lady. Stepping backward, his canine features disappear into a welter of station activity. Carol watches his receding fi for a moment, then simultaneously placing the key into he purse, she turns and begins moving towards the Cocktail Lounge.

head_text.subj: EMPTY CAGES STACKED ALONG A WOODEN WALL

text: A YOUNG KITTEN IN A CARDBOARD BOX wrestling with the barr of a .44. A thick veined hand gently rubs the gun over th fur along the cat's neck and backbone. RUDY BUTLER IS PREOCCUPIED WITH THE CAT, giving little attention to the thirtyish Man standing nearby. HAROLD CLINTON puts away a large syringe then snaps shut medical bag. Rudy lies across a cot in one corner of the like Animal Hospital. The large room is lined with stalls cages and pens, many of them vacant. The wonded criminal is bare-chested. A plaster cast has b attached to his left arm and shoulder. FRAN CLINTON SITS ON A HIGH WOODEN STOOL opposite   Rudy. years younger than her husband, tight sweater and   skirt bright scarlet fingernail polish, well-built, her   face suggests sensuality. Fran's bare, milk-white legs   are c under her rumpled skirt.
(to Harold) What's the damage?
Collar bone is broken. No infection yet... the bandages should be changed twice a day.
I got a nurse in mind.
(going along, oblivious to the implication) The glucose will begin working in half an hour. You'll feel better then...
(flashing a grin despite the pain) The three of us are going to do some traveling. We're going to take your car to El Paso.
That's not possible. We can't leave here... we've got all this.
Rudy smiles at Mrs. Clinton. He's never met Fran before, he's known her for years.
Is it possible, Mrs. Clinton?
(scared, but trying to be friendly) Just... tell us what you want. Rudy looks back down at the gun and cat. The following silence is like a scream. Finally:
What kind of car do you have, Harold?
(cutting in) A Ford... We have a Ford.

That's good. That's very good. Now Harold, you go out and gas up the Ford, check the oil and tires, we don't want any problems on the road. One more thing... If anybody but you comes back... He points the gun at Mrs. Clinton.
(continuing) She gets her clock fixed right away... You understand that, Harold? A long pause.
You do what he says, Harold.

After you come back I'll listen while you make some phone calls, tell a few friends you've got to leave for a week or two... You have to call another Vet about the animals. You tell him to come over and take good care of them starting tomorrow... no slip-ups on that. They got to be looked after...
We really don't have too many friends.
They don't think he married well.
(smiling) That makes things a little easier for us then, doesn't it?
Carol sits in the bar. A young SOLDIER approaches and sit down at the counter next to her. She is finishing a vodka gimlet.
(to a bartender) Beer. Carol glances at her watch.
(continuing - begins with the obvious) Guess you have to catch a train?
pink-cheeked and freckle-faced, he has to shave maybe twice a week; twenty-one years old, not good-looking (his best feature is his gentle, easy grin) and not a hustler. He just wats to meet a girl.
(not too patronizing) That's right.
Me, too. Got twenty-four days of furlough and I'm goin' home. The soldier's beer arrives.
Where's home?
Utah, the Bee-Hive state. I'm from Orem, right near Salt Lake ... Say, you wouldn't happen to be a Mormon, would you?
(chuckles) No, I'm not.
Me, neither. There's about twelve people in the state that aren't Mormons and I'm one of them.
That certainly makes you kind of special...
(awkward) Yeah... I guess it does. Carol pushes aside her glass.
(c ont inuing) You wouldn't be taking the train to Salt Lake, would you?
(smiles across to him) No, I'm afraid not.
I never have any luck. Carol smiles at the soldier. Her features suddenly freeze she glances toward the entrance to the bar.
DOC STANDS LOOKING AT CAROL and the soldier.

head_text.subj: STANDS AND PAUSES FOR A MOMENT.

text: I really hope you have a nice trip.
Thanks. I hope yours is okay, too. Carol moves towards the exit. The soldier quietly sips his beer, his face a bit grim.
They look at each other...
Where's the suitcase? Carol continues looking at Doc for a moment. Then, suddenly moves past him, leading him out into the m lobby.

CAROL EMERGES FROM THE COCKTAIL LOUNGE followed by Doc. They cross to the lockers. She retrieves the key from her purse and thrusts it into proper slot. It doesn't turn. Puzzled she tries again, th forcing the key, shakes the lock violently. Her eyes widening into a quiet panic, she next looks at t locker number and then the number on the key. Her feature are now totally ashen. She walks up the bank of lockers... puts the key in anoth locker, the door opens, the compartment is empty. Carol turns away from the locker, eyes glazed with fear.. Doc at her shoulder.
A man helped me open it...
(deceptive calm) And switched keys.
He must have.
(angrily) It isn't another boyfriend, is it? Carol winces, containing her anger.
(continuing - icily) How long ago.
Fifteen minutes.
Sure? Carol nods.
(continuing - with quick calculation) He'd figure you for longer, enough time to try another hit. He's probably still in the station. As Doc pushes Carol forward.
(continuing - lashing out) There better be a guy with the

(lashing back) You bastard... Walking at a rapid pace, they start through the station, forcing their speed, clutching Carol under her elbow. The reach the main concourse after moving down the length of promenade... eyes straining. CAROL STOPS SUDDENLY. SHE STARES DOWN THE LONG CORRIDOR h eyes finding the thief. He stands near another bank of lockers, the black suitcase at his feet. THE THIEF LOOKS UP AT CAROL - virtually within the same moment that she spots him. His expression never changes. takes a step towards her, smiling... Then, with a movemen that is both abrupt and casual, he snatches up the money and disappears behind the constant traffic of train patro DOC HAS SEEN THE THIEF. Recognizing the suitcase he moves immediately after him. Carol follows Doc but is unable to keep up. She watches as Doc vanishes behind the row of lockers. CAROL ROUNDS THE LAST LOCKER IN THE ROW but both men have disappeared from view. She sags back against the edge of metal compartments, exhausted, fearful.
(indistinct above the roar of the station) Attention please.
The Flyer now boarding at gate three. The Flyer now boarding at gate three. Carol again raises her eyes. Still breathless, her face g with moisture.
FRAN IS STILL SEATED ON THE STOOL. Rudy stares at her fro the cot. Harold is now absent.
I don't think you have to worry much about Harold. He won't do anything.
(he speaks very politely) That right?
You can trust him...
How long have you been married?
Two years.
Can he trust you?
(smiles) That's what matters, isn't it? Rudy continues looking at her.
Come over here a minute... He gestures with his gun. Fran crosses the distance slowl moving with apprehension.
Look, I'm not going to be any trouble to you either, fact is, this may sound funny, but maybe you and I could be close friends... Rudy gestures her closer...
(continuing) You don't always have to have your gun out. I'll get whatever you want. Really, I will... Fran smiles. She is now standing over the cot, looking directly down at Rudy. He jerks her down.

(still polite) Get rid of that nail polish, I don't like it, and when I tell you to come over here you move fast. You and I are going to get along because I've known a lot of people like you, so don't tell me about it because I got your ticket going in. Now get up and get that paint of your fingers... okay? Rudy smiles.

DOC MOVING LIKE A GUN DOG ON THE HUNT between the rows of lockers; catching sight of the thief momentarily, he clos in. After a series of criss-crossed movements among the banke locker corriders, Doc again loses sight of the thief as t slender criminal dodges off onto a main passenger concour Doc is faster and more agile than the thief, but the stat is unfamiliar territory to him. Both Doc and the Thief mo carefully, they must not arouse enough attention to make themselves conspicuous, thus risking police interference. THE THIEF HURRIES ALONG THE MAIN CONCOURSE weaving betwee the incoming and departing passengers that dot the long corridor. DOC IN PURSUIT DOWN THE CONCOURSE, he passes several seal off departure/arrival gates. THE THIEF STEPS OFF THE CONCOURSE INTO GATE THREE, an ope stairway winding downward. DOC FOLLOWS HIS QUARRY DOWN THE STAIRWAY to the train are where he immediately skips over the winding ramp and onto loading platform. Emerging from the short tunnel, Doc isn surprised that the Thief is again nowhere in sight. Doc s behind a pillar -- he waits watchfully... After a moment two, the Thief edges out from behind another column and starts back up the platform towards the concourse.

Doc moves quickly to intercept his opponent but, as the T spots his approach, he turns and Joins several passengers scurrying toward the awaiting train... THE FLYER STANDS GLEAMING AT TRACKSIDE, perpendicular to boarding gate. Two doors to the train stand open, one in pullman section, the other entrance admitting day coach passengers.

about-to-depart passengers... the Flyer comes into sight, visible on the next level below. THE CONDUCTOR - AT TRACKSIDE - STANDS SMILING BROADLY by coach entrance. He grins at the boarding PASSENGERS as he speaks to a nearby BRAKEMAN. The Thief skirts around a baggage-laden elderly COUPLE and moves up the two-step an into the rail car passageway. DOC MOVING QUICKLY AGAIN. He sees the Thief slip past the conductor and into the train. THE THIEF IS NOW INSIDE THE DAY COACH. He heads toward th forward compartments. DOC EXPERTLY SQUIRMS THROUGH THE BOARDING THRONG and disappears past the conductor up into the passenger car vestibule.

CAROL WATCHES AS A BLONDISH MAN in a grey suit skips aboa the Flyer standing below. She is unable to get a clear lo at the man, and is unsure as to whether or not it was Doc She hesitates, then moves forward to Gate Three which wil take her down to trackside... Carol stands at the edge of the gate -- the last of the c having already passed through. She hesitates again, stari down at the shining train.

THE AISLE IS CLOGGED WITH PASSENGERS. People hesitate ove their selection of seats, put baggage into overhead racks clumsily remove their overcoats... The Thief continues to move forward, squirming around the passengers at a hurrie but controlled pace.

head_text.subj: AT THE END OF A PULLMAN

text: DOC ENTERS, THREADING HIS WAY FORWARD, scanning faces. He one car behind the Thief and losing ground, due to the fa that Doc must carefully note the occupants of each seat a passes. Doc is further delayed by a WOMAN blocking the ai She struggles painfully, trying to fit a suitcase into an overhead carriage. Doc, with the most forced of smiles, reaches up to help h 30? THE THIEF MOVES THROUGH ANOTHER VESTIBULE and into an empty car -- now unobserved, he immediately breaks into a run.
The passengers have become fewer and fewer as he nears th front of the train.

head_text.subj: THE THIEF RUNS THROUGH ANOTHER VESTIBULE AND INTO A SMOKE

text: This car also deserted, he maintains his trotting pace, swinging the heavy suitcase as he goes... reaching the en the smoker, he enters the next vestibule and attempts to into the following car, but the Thief is brought to a hal the sudden dead end of the passageway. The next car holds only baggage. He has reached furthest forward passenger c The Thief desperately tries to open the vestibule door, hoping to escape by jumping off the train, but the doors tightly locked. He begins to retrace his steps. DOC MOVES CAREFULLY INTO THE NEXT CAR FORWARD, still unknowingly two cars behind the Thief.

head_text.subj: THE THIEF PASSES BACK TO THE VESTIBULE AT THE REAR OF THE

text: SMOKER, his eye suddenly catching the Men's Lounge. He tr the door -- locked. The Thief snaps out a pen knife, pick the lock with a deft movement. Passengers are visible beh him as he works, filtering into the pullman car following smoker. None of them notes his activity. The restroom doo swings open.

The Thief immediately snaps the bolt-lock shut behind him crosses the small, murky room and tries to lift the windo He strains mightily but the glass remains hopelessly jammed... DOC ENTERS THE FINAL PASSENGER CAR, notes the half 313 do travelers and continues moving forward, going next into t smoker.

THE SMOKING CAR IS EMPTY, although several Passengers and PORTER enter it moments after Doc leads the way. Doc pass through the length of the car, moves into the vestibule a like the Thief a few moments before, finds his passage blocked by the baggage car. Doc hesitates, then turns and begins going back in the opposite direction. DOC STOPS AT THE MEN'S LOUNGE -- staring hard at the door a moment. He tries the handle. The door remains firmly sh
(appearing suddenly at Doc's shoulder)

Be open five minutes out of the station. Doc nods and moves away, continuing to retrace his steps toward his point of entrance onto the train. THE THIEF, HAVING ABANDONED THE JAMMED WINDOW, is now und the snaps and straps holding the suitcase closed. The lid pulls upward and stacks of money appear under his hands. Thief grabs a money pad, runs his thumb over it, then sho the stack of greenbacks into his coat's inside breast poc DOC MOVES WITH DETERMINATION back through the passenger c
THE THIEF HAS AGAIN CLOSED THE SUITCASE. He nervously loo about his tight-walled sanctuary, then crosses back to th window and stares out through a corner of the pane. He pu the shade lower.

METAL WHEELS GRIND AGAINST THE RAILS, the train SHUDDERS, then begins to move forward. THE THIEF IS WATCHING THROUGH THE MEN'S ROOM WINDOW as th train edges forward. His body suddenly tightens. He sees outside the train, walking slowly between a narrow passag moving passenger cars and several parked tinders.

CARS, walking cautiously ahead. As the Flyer continues to move slowly forward, Doc disappears from view. THE THIEF ALLOWS HIMSELF A QUICK SMILE. Turning away from window he picks up the suitcase, unbolts the lock and ste back out into the vestibule.

AT THE BACK OF THE SMOKER, the Thief seats himself next t window and places the suitcase on the cushioned chair opposite from him. In the forward position of the car, we behind the Thief's back, a dozen Passengers are scattered about the lounge chairs. A Conductor appears at the end o the smoker opposite the Thief and begins to collect and p tickets. As the train begins to pick up speed, the Thief lifts an abandoned copy of the newpaper off the cushion next to hi He glances at the front page, then unfolds the width of t paper. As a precaution against regaining poverty, the Thi rests one foot against the suitcase. All seems secure. Th Doc sits down next to the Thief.

head_text.subj: DOC COMPANIONABLY SLIDES AN ARM BEHIND THE BACK OP THE

text: THIEF'S NECK, pulling him close. DOC

(softly almost gently) When you pop a lock don't mark it. The Thief's knife instantly flashes into his hand, but be he can bring it into play, Doc catches his arms. THE KNIFE IS TIGHTLY WEDGED INTO THE THIEF'S HAND. Doc's fingers are vise-like at his wrist. THE OTHER PASSENGERS REMAIN PRE-OCCUPIED AT THE OTHER end the car, taking no note of the quiet encounter. THE CONDUCTOR IS STILL AT THE OPPOSITE END OF THE CAR fro Doc and the Thief. He continues collecting and punching fares.

head_text.subj: CAROL IS EXITING. THERE IS AN ANNOUNCEMENT OVER THE

text: LOUDSPEAKER -- the train has left.

THE CONDUCTOR AS SEEN BY THE THIEF'S WIDENING EYES. He methodically punches the tickets, never looking more than seats ahead. THE THIEF'S EYES BULGE AS DOC CHOPS HIM ON THE WINDPIPE. Thief goes out. Is he dead? DOC CHOPS HIM AGAIN. IF HE ISN'T DEAD HE LOOKS IT. Doc pulls the Thief's hat down over his head.

head_text.subj: CAROL CROSSES INTO THE STATION, TAKES A DEEP BREATH.

text: Sits... waiting. The soldier comes by, stops. She doesn't recognize anything.

head_text.subj: THE CONDUCTOR ARRIVES AT THE LOUNGE CHAIRS WHERE DOC AND

text: thief are seated. He stops in the aisleway, expectantly leaning in Doc's direction. CONDUCTOR
Tickets? As Doc takes out his wallet, peels a fifty out and gives to him. DOC
End of the line. Two. CONDUCTOR
(grumpily) All right. The conductor cuts the fare receipt and begins to make change.

head_text.subj: THE THIEF SITS FACING THE WINDOW LOOKING VERY DEAD
RUDY SITS IN THE BACK SEAT AS HAROLD CAUTIOUSLY MOTORS

text: DOWN the highway. With his one good arm, Rudy cares for t kitten resting in the cardboard box on the back seat. RUDY
Talk a little, Harold, loosen up... good for you. Harold works his jaw, his grip tightens on the wheel. FRAN
(chuckling at Harold) Something ought to loosen him up ... how comes we're going to El Paso, Rudy? RUDY
I Just want to find a suitcase.

BEYNON'S BODY REMAINS OUT OF SIGHT behind the overturned kitchen table... a small trickle of blood oozes out from under one of the table legs. The Accountant stands with Cully, Hayhoe and Swain starin down at Beynon's body. ACCOUNTANT
They may still be going to Nogales. SWAIN
What about Laughlin in El Paso? ACCOUNTANT
Cover both, get someone down there... either Rudy and McCoy's got half a million. SWAIN
They've got to switch cars. ACCOUNTANT
Put out the word. HAYHOE
(looking back at Beynon) What about Jack? ACCOUNTANT
Tonight... take him out in the country, throw him down a dry well, if you can find one.

AS DOC THUMBS IDLY THROUGH THE NEWSPAPER. He is suddenly showered with spurting water. He lowers the paper and loo to the aisle, seeing: A SEVEN YEAR OLD BLACK PANTHER, dressed appropriately and holding a water pistol. KID
Stick 'em up! Doc looks at the brat. KID (CONT'D)
(continuing) I'm gonna shoot you...
He squeezes the pistol's trigger, two bursts of water lan Doc's shirt front. Doc continues staring at the boy. The looks hard at Doc, not giving an inch. DOC
Come here a second... Doc takes the boy's arm, gently pulls him closer. DOC (CONT'D)

(continuing) Look, I'm sure you're a nice kid and that your mother's nearby... Now you better get back to her real quick or I'm going to break your little arm... okay? Doc releases the boy. The kid looks at Doc for a moment t bursts into tears and retreats at a dead run back down th passenger car aisleway. Doc again lifts the paper, turnin the sports page.

DOC LIFTS THE SUITCASE AS THE CONDUCTOR APPEARS at the vestibule at the opposite end of the car and announces th next stop. Doc prepares to get off. The passenger car rem sparsely populated. No one occupies the seats near the corpse.

CAROL SITS WATCHING THE PEOPLE -- she gets up, doesn't kn where to go... sits down again... fear and anticipation o her face... stands up... ready to go where? Ready to sit again, she looks up. DOC CROSSES SLOWLY TO HER CARRYING THE SUITCASE. Carol reacts... pleased to see him... pleased that he's back... until. DOC
(steely) Your kind of mistakes are going to land me back in Huntsville.
CAROL
(nailing him) I wouldn't worry Doc. I can always get you out... I'll screw every prison official in Texas if I have to. DOC
Texas is a big state. CAROL
I can handle it. DOC
I'll bet you can. CAROL
You'd do the same for me, wouldn't you, Doc? (rising tone) If I was caught, wouldn't you? Doc is silent. After a long pause. CAROL (CONT'D)
(continuing - quietly) When we had trouble before it was different. DOC
(nodding) You don't like the way things are, I don't like the way things CAROL
What do you want to do? DOC
Maybe we should split up... I'll cut the money with you. CAROL
Do you mean that?
I mean it. A long pause. Maybe she wonders; what if he is lying but if he isn't? Temptation? She makes up her mind. CAROL
No... I don't want to leave.

DOC AND CAROL WATCH THROUGH THE DOUBLE WINDOWS AS THE tra yard lights of a town go strobing by. EXT. SECOND TRAIN CONCOURSE. DOC AND CAROL COME DOWN OUT OF THE GANGWAY OF ANOTHER tra and turn up the pavement toward the main part of the depo Doc continues holding the suitcase as they walk. DOC
We'll grab a room for tonight then you go out tomorrow and buy yourself some new clothes, pick some up for me... Grab some food now, paper bag it, we eat in the room. CAROL
(cutting in) You've got all the answers. What about when they find the body on the train? DOC
When they find it, they find it. To the cops a description's only good if there's a channe for it, and there's no connection between that stiff and robbery. CAROL
You've got it all figured. DOC
(looking at Carol and thinking about Beynon) No... there's a couple of things I'm still working on.
Like what? But Doc doesn't answer.

DOC LIES NEXT TO CAROL. Carol is eating a hamburger wrapp in wax paper. She passes one over to Doc along with some greasy french fries and a couple of napkins . The Suitcase has been placed on the small writing desk ac the room. Doc silently munches his hamburger.
Doc glances at the poster rolled up. Carol hasn't put it on the wall yet.
THE TRAIN GOES CLICKETY CLICK THROUGH THE NIGHT, the youn panther is stalking and prowling among the sleeping passengers. His Mother catches him, takes him back to his seat.

head_text.subj: CAROL IS BUSY UNBANDING THE MONEY PADS. A LARGE STACK OF

text: discarded wrappers have been placed in a metal trash can her leg. Behind her, Doc, now in his undershirt, reads a Texas newspaper. CAROL CONTINUES TO LOOSEN THE GREENBACKS. She is surround on the double bed by stacks of money. She lights a match, drops it into the wastebasket. The money bands quickly bu into flames, consume themselves, then die back into crink ashes. DOC
(not looking up) There may be a hunting party. CAROL
Why, there's nothing on the news? DOC
